column1: The COVID-19 pandemic in Malaysia is part of the ongoing worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus was confirmed to have reached Malaysia in late January 2020
column2: when it was detected on travellers from China arriving in Johor via Singapore on 25 January
column3: following the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hubei
column4: China. Reported cases remained relatively low at first and were largely confined to imported cases
column5: until localised clusters began to emerge in March; the largest cluster was linked to a Tablighi Jamaat religious gathering held in Sri Petaling
column6: Kuala Lumpur in late February and early March
column7: leading to massive spikes in local cases and an exportation of cases to neighbouring countries. Within a few weeks
column8: Malaysia had recorded the largest cumulative number of confirmed COVID-19 infections in Southeast Asia
column9: breaching the 2
column10: 000 active cases mark by the end of March
column11: from fewer than 30 cases at the beginning of the month. By 16 March
column12: the virus was reported in every state and federal territory in the country.

column1: The medical response to the outbreak is overseen by Director-General of Health Noor Hisham Abdullah under the Health Ministry of two successive governments. Preparations to stockpile equipment
column2: detect and monitor cases
column3: and treat COVID-19 patients were reported to have been initiated as early as 6 January 2020
column4: following a World Health Organization (WHO) report on a late-December 2019 outbreak of "pneumonia of unknown cause" in the city of Wuhan
column5: Hubei. As jumps in cases began to occur in early March and the Yang di-Pertuan Agong expressed great concern over the escalation of the outbreak
column6: measures to combat the outbreak were later announced by the Prime Minister of Malaysia via live nationwide telecast on 13 March 2020. By 16 March
column7: a nationwide "Movement Control Order" (MCO)
column8: intended to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 through social distancing
column9: was announced to be in effect between 18 and 31 March. The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) also published a federal gazette on 18 March 2020 that restricts individuals from travelling to other states that have been declared as coronavirus-affected areas. On 25 March
column10: the MCO was extended by an addition two weeks
column12: as the rate of new cases per day remained consistently high. The MCO was further announced to be extended until 28 April on 10 April
column13: and to 12 May on 23 April. A gradual easing of restrictions was implemented in stages
column14: first with the announcement of a "Conditional Movement Control Order" (CMCO) on 1 May
column15: which allows most businesses to open on 4 May under strict standards of practice
column16: followed by a "Recovery Movement Control Order" (RMCO) from 10 June. Originally slated to expire on 31 August
column17: the RMCO has been further extended to 31 December 2020
column18: with selected sectors remaining closed and strict travel restrictions from multiple countries remaining in effect due to continued detection of imported cases.Initially reporting the highest number of cases in Southeast Asia in March and early-April
column19: daily active cases in Malaysia have declined steadily from a peak of 2
column20: 596 in early April to a fluctuation of less than 250 cases by late June. The country's case count has since been eclipsed by other Southeast Asian countries of the Philippines (on 14 April)
column24: but the extent of its outbreak remains more severe than several other Southeast Asian countries of Thailand
column30: with a higher fatality count than in Singapore
column36: and East Timor. Periodic case spikes from subsequent clusters within local communities
column40: and health facilities continue to be reported since the initial outbreak
column41: of which the most serious since mid-2020 is an outbreak originating in Sabah in September 2020.

column1: == Nomenclature ==
The Ministry of Health originally referred to this disease as the "2019 Novel Coronavirus". Some media referred this disease as "Wuhan Coronavirus". During the onset of the outbreak
column2: the Malaysian media called it the "radang paru-paru Wuhan" in Malay
column3: meaning "Wuhan Pneunomia". Then some media changed the name to "radang paru-paru koronavirus baru" (new coronavirus pneumonia) in Malay. The Ministry of Health and most media now refer to the disease as "COVID-19"
column4: as suggested by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 11 February 2020.

column1: == Background ==
On 12 January 2020
column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that a novel coronavirus was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City
column3: Hubei Province
column4: China
column5: which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019.

column1: Unlike the SARS outbreak of 2003
column2: the case fatality ratio for COVID-19 has been much lower
column3: but the transmission has been significantly greater
column4: with a significant total death toll.

column1: == Case-related events ==
Malaysia reported its first three cases on 25 January 2020
column2: all of whom were Chinese nationals who had visited the country. By 30 January
column3: the number of cases had risen to eight. In response
column4: the Ministry of Health published guidelines on the virus and established designated hospitals in all of Malaysia's states and federal territories to manage any positive cases. Local authorities also advised Malaysians traveling to China to stay away from animal farms and markets in that country. Following several earlier suspected cases involving Chinese nationals
column5: the Sabah and Sarawak state governments suspended all direct flights with China.In response to a surge of cases originating in South Korea
column6: the Malaysian Government imposed a ban on visitors from South Korea on 26 February
column7: including foreign nationals who had visited Daegu and Cheongdo. Malaysia experienced a spike in COVID-19 cases following a four-day Tablighi Jamaat event that was held at Kuala Lumpur's "Masjid Jamek Sri Petaling" between 27 February and 1 March 2020. By 20 March
column8: 48% of the country's COVID-19 cases (3
column9: 347) had been linked to the Sri Petaling tabligh cluster. In response to the rise in cases nationally
column10: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that Malaysia would enter into lockdown on 18 March 2020. On 17 March
column11: Malaysia reported its first two deaths from the coronavirus: a 60-year-old priest from Emmanuel Baptist Church in Kuching
column12: Sarawak and a 34-year-old participant of the Muslim religious gathering in Sri Petaling from Johor Bahru
column14: a spike in 217 new cases was reported
column16: 333. The Director-General of Health Noor Hisham Abdullah attributed this spike to active detection in areas affected by Enhanced Movement Controlled Order
column17: a stricter version of the MCO. In response to rising cases
column18: the Government extended the movement control order until 28 April.On 1 May
column19: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that the country's lockdown would be eased on 4 May
column20: allowing most businesses to reopen while maintaining a ban on mass gatherings. From 21 May
column21: a spike of cases occurred among detainees at immigration detention centres in Bukit Jalil and Semenyih
column23: causing the number of cases to rise to a total of 7
column25: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin entered into quarantine for 14 days after an official who attended a post-Cabinet briefing the previous day tested positive for COVID-19.On 1 June
column27: 857 cases were reported while the total number of recovered and deaths stood at 6
column29: Director-General Noor Hisham encouraged members of the public to wear face masks following advice from the World Health Organization that it helped to reduce infections. By 30 June
column32: 639 cases. The number of recovered had risen to 8
column33: 534 while the death toll stood at 121.On 1 July
column34: there were 144 active cases with a total of 8
column36: 375 had recovered while the death toll stood at 121. On 20 July
column37: Prime Minister Muhyiddin announced that the Malaysian Government would consider making face masks compulsory following the emergence of 13 clusters after the relaxation of lockdown restrictions on travel and businesses the previous month. By 31 July
column38: there were 207 active cases with a total of 8
column39: 976 cases. The number of recovered had risen to 8
column40: 644 while the death toll had risen to 125.On 1 August
column41: there were 213 active cases with a total of 8
column43: 647 have recovered while the death toll stayed at 125. By 31 August
column44: there were 160 active cases with a total of 9
column46: 054 had recovered while the death toll had risen to 127.At least two regional outbreaks have occurred since July 2020. In late-July and August in Kedah
column47: several clusters emerged due to lapses by locals to adhere to standards of practice
column48: leading to cases in Kedah as well as neighbouring Perlis and Penang. In September 2020
column49: a major outbreak in Sabah initially detected in two prisons led to community spread within the state
column52: and the detection of infections throughout the country through returnees from Sabah following the 2020 Sabah state election. Malaysian authorities also attributed the surge of cases in Sabah to the entry of illegal immigrants from Indonesia. The country passed the 10
column56: were reported between the month ends of August and September. By 30 September
column58: 124 active cases with a total of 11
column60: 967 had recovered while the death toll had risen to 136.

column1: == Preventive measures by government ==
=== Movement Control Order ===
Beginning from 15 March
column2: Malaysia saw a significant jump in active cases. The Prime Minister of Malaysia held a live nationwide telecast on 16 March 2020 at 10:00 pm (UTC+8) to announce the decision of the federal government in implementing the Movement Control Order (MCO). Based on the live addressing that evening
column3: six restrictions have been imposed:

column1: The public is prohibited to mass gather or attend massive events including religious
column2: sports
column3: social and cultural activities. All worshiping locations and business premises should be closed except for supermarkets
column4: public markets
column5: grocery stores and convenience stores that sells everyday necessities. For Muslims
column6: all religious activities in mosques including Friday prayers are adjourned in line with decision made on 15 March 2020 by the Special Muzakarah Committee Meeting of the National Fatwa Council.

column1: Malaysians returning from abroad are required to undergo health check and self-quarantine for 14 days.
Tourists and foreign visitors are restricted to enter the country.
Closure of all kindergartens
column2: government and private schools
column3: including daily schools
column4: boarding schools
column5: international schools
column6: tahfiz centres and other primary
column7: secondary and pre-university institutions.

column1: Closure of all public and private higher education institution (IPTs) and skill training institutes.
Closure of all government and private premises except for essential services (water
column2: electricity
column3: energy
column4: telecommunications
column5: postal
column6: transportation
column7: irrigation
column8: oil
column9: gas
column10: fuel
column24: retail and food supply).The order was originally to be in effect from 18 March to 31 March
column25: but has been extended four times as additional two-week "phases" over the course of two months.:

column1: Phase 2
column2: announced on 25 March
column3: extends the MCO to 14 April
column4: as new cases continued to climb.

column1: Phase 3
column2: announced on 10 April
column3: extends the MCO to 28 April
column4: as the number of cases was projected by the WHO to peak in mid-April.

column1: Phase 4
column2: announced on 23 April
column3: extends the MCO to 12 May.

column1: On 10 May
column2: the Conditional Movement Control Order was extended until 9 June
column3: the fourth extension since 18 March. Unlike the others
column4: this extension is scheduled to last about a month as Phase 1 of post-lockdown of the restrictions.

column1: On 6 June
column2: the Director-General confirmed that the movement control order would remain in force since Malaysia is still being monitored under the Prevention and Control of Infections Diseases Act 1988. On 7 June
column3: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that the Conditional Movement Control Order would end on 9 June
column4: with the country moving into the Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) phase as in Phase 2 of post-lockdown for the rest of 2020.

column1: On 28 August
column2: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that the Recovery Movement Control Order would be extended until 31 December 2020 in view of the second wave of cases.

column1: === Epidemic prevention for immigration ===
With the movement control order put in place since 18 March
column2: all citizens have been prohibited from leaving the country with foreigners also prohibited from entering the country.Since the first wave of the virus was reported
column3: thermal scanners were introduced at border points with the Malaysian health authorities placed on high alert. After the ban on travellers from Hubei on 27 January
column4: the Malaysian federal government extended its ban to the Chinese provinces of Jiangsu and Zhejiang on 9 February. The state of Sabah expanded their travel restriction to all points of entry by air
column5: sea or land starting 8 February
column6: involving everyone except Sabahan citizens with recent travel history to mainland China within 14 days
column7: while Sabahan citizens with such travel history must undergo a 14-day quarantine at home. The state of Sarawak closed its borders to all Chinese visitors with immediate effect on 1 February
column8: except for people with employment passes
column9: student passes or long-term social visit passes. However
column10: those visitors were required to undergo self-quarantine at home for 14 days. With the increasing cases in South Korea
column11: both Sabah and Sarawak government began to extended its travel restrictions into the country from 1 March. On 4 March
column12: Sarawak further added Italy and Iran into its travel restrictions list.On 5 March
column13: Malaysia added seven regions towards its travel restriction list
column15: Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy; Hokkaido in Japan; and Tehran
column16: Qom and Gilan in Iran. By 10 March
column17: Sabah also began to added Italy and Iran into its restrictions list. On 11 March
column18: Malaysia announced a full restriction on foreign nationals directly from Italy
column19: Iran and South Korea starting from 13 March
column20: while Malaysians from those countries will be quarantined for 14 days. Following the 13 March Denmark lockdown
column21: Malaysia has added the country into its travel ban list effective from 14 March.On 6 April
column22: visitors from the following regions can enter Malaysia by air exclusively: Angola
column41: Rwanda and Western Sahara. On 1 September
column42: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that long-term pass holders from India
column43: Indonesia and the Philippines would be unable to enter Malaysia due to a spike of cases in those countries effective 7 September.On 7 September
column44: the Immigration Department banned nationals from 23 countries with a high number of COVID-19 cases including the United States
column65: Philippines and Indonesia. The ban includes permanent residents
column66: participants of the "Malaysia My Second Home" program

column1: === Overseas travel alert and quarantine arrangements ===
The following are warnings and quarantine arrangements for inbound and outbound travel:
=== Testing and treatment centres ===
On 5 January
column2: the National Crisis Preparedness and Response Centre (CPRC) under the Ministry of Health Malaysia began operation. By early-February
column3: 57 hospitals were reported to provide screening services for coronavirus
column4: while among them
column5: 26 government hospitals are responsible for the confirmation of coronavirus and the suspected patients. With the rapid increase of infections
column6: a further total of 409 sites across the country have been gazetted by the federal government as quarantine zones for coronavirus patients comprising public universities
column7: community colleges
column8: technical institutes
column9: former National Service (PLKN) camps
column10: training centres
column11: polytechnics and hotels owned by federal ministries
column13: agencies and statutory bodies. As of 2 May 2020
column18: 100 beds on standby) at 26 hospital extension centres/low-risk COVID-19 centres
column21: 059 ventilators have been allocated for COVID-19 patients.On 8 April
column22: a consortium of associated laboratories in Malaysia comprising Gribbles Pathology
column23: Quantum Diagnostics and Clinipath Malaysia launched the country's largest COVID-19 collection and testing programme to increase testing capacity. Malaysian public universities also providing research and scientific capacity with 10 diagnostic laboratories at public higher learning institutions in the country nationwide have been called as part of a joint initiative by the Higher Education and Science
column24: Technology and Innovation Ministries to help the Health Ministry in conducting 16
column25: 500 coronavirus tests daily. In spite of further capabilities to conduct more tests
column26: the Health Ministry had stated that the country is yet to find its suitable rapid test kits to solved the increasing backlog of pending result cases along with the revelation that the existing supply of coronavirus reagents test kits could only last for another week which causing the Health Ministry to source from other countries including Singapore. As a response
column27: the Federation of Chinese Associations Malaysia (Hua Zong) has called on the federal government to ensure sufficient coronavirus test kit reagents for the country especially among the Malaysia's eastern states of Sabah and Sarawak which are reportedly struggling to source test kit reagents.The Solidarity trial
column28: launched by WHO to compare the safety and effectiveness of treatment protocols which included chloroquine
column32: would be conducted in nine government hospitals across the country.On 3 July
column33: Minister of Health Adham Baba announced that both Malaysian citizens and foreign nationals traveling to Malaysia would be required to pay fees when undergoing COVID-19 tests under the Prevention and Control of Infectious Diseases (Fee for Coronavirus Diseases 2019 (COVID-19) Detection Test) Regulations 2020
column34: which came into effect on 29 June.

column1: ==== Vaccine research ====
In mid-March
column2: Malaysian Vaccines and Pharmaceuticals (MVP) Sdn Bhd reportedly pleaded for co-operation and support from the federal government
column3: with its executive director claiming that their company faced multiple postponed meetings in an attempt to meet the health minister to request for a sample from the Institute of Medical Research (IMR) of Malaysia. The IMR was set to begin testing existing local vaccines in collaboration with the MVP and University of Malaya's Tropical Infectious Diseases Research and Education Centre (TIDREC) by 25 March. The local vaccine testing will be conducted in UM's TIDREC laboratory
column4: which is one of Malaysia's modular biosafety level 3 (BSL3) facilities previously used to study highly pathogenic agents such as MERS coronavirus and Nipah virus with the vaccines to be firstly tested on the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV)
column5: which is an avian coronavirus
column6: as previous research shows that the IBV in poultry has high genetic similarity with the human coronavirus.On 6 October
column7: the engineering company Bintai Kinden entered into a distribution and licensing agreement (DLA) with the American–based firm Generex Biotechnology Corp and its subsidiary NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology Inc to distribute their COVID-19 vaccine in Malaysia through its subsidiary Bintai Healthcare. The company will also have the first right of refusal to commercially exploit the vaccine within Australia
column8: New Zealand and the global halal market.

column1: === Repatriation of Malaysian nationals abroad ===
The Malaysian government has made the repatriation of its citizens abroad a priority; beginning with the first repatriations from China. During the first repatriation
column2: two persons were found to be infected with the virus and were subsequently quarantined and treated in the country until they have fully recovered.On 21 March
column3: a total of 212 Malaysians arrived from Uzbekistan through a flight sponsored by the Uzbekistan government which is also being used to repatriated Uzbek citizens in Malaysia. On that same day
column4: 372 Malaysians departed Tamil Nadu on two chartered flights. On 22 March
column5: it was reported that the Malaysian government was waiting for the Indian government's permission to organise six more flights to evacuate Malaysians still in India.On 31 March
column6: the Defence Minister Datuk Seri Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that all Malaysians returning from overseas would have to undergo a compulsory two-week quarantine at designated quarantine centres around the country. That same day
column7: Deputy Foreign Minister Kamaruddin Jaffar confirmed that 4
column8: 374 Malaysians were stranded abroad due to the travel restrictions and delays created by the global coronavius pandemic. This figure only consists of Malaysians who had bought return tickets but were unable to return due to travel restrictions. According to Kamaruddin
column10: 156 Malaysians are stranded in India
column17: the Johor Immigration Department announced that Malaysians with Singaporean work permits would be required to take swab tests in Singaporean clinics and hospitals to show that they are free of the coronavirus to return to Johor. That same day
column18: Deputy Foreign Minister Kamaruddin announced that the Government had brought back 4
column19: 811 stranded Malaysians from affected countries. He also upgraded the number of Malaysians stranded abroad to 2

column1: === Repatriation of foreign nationals ===
On 18 April
column2: the United States Embassy in Kuala Lumpur advised US nationals in Malaysia wishing to return home to make commercial arrangements as soon as possible unless they had made plans to remain in Malaysia. The US Embassy also clarified that the United States Government was not planning to charter flights to evacuate its citizens. Based on the January 29 circular from the Malaysia Ministry of Health
column3: foreigners in Malaysia will not have to pay for COVID-19 testing or outpatient treatment at government hospitals; this announcement was reiterated by the health director-general Datuk Dr. Noor Hisham Abdullah on March 23
column5: when asked to clarify a statement made by the prime minister that foreigners would have to pay for COVID-19 testing.On 16 May
column6: the Malaysian Government announced that it would be allowing "Malaysia My Second Home" (MM2H) programme members who were stranded overseas to return to Malaysia from 17 May. However
column7: they must undergo testing for COVID-19 in the place that they are in and must be certified free of the coronavirus in order to enter Malaysia. They will also be quarantined for 14 days.

column1: === Bans on mass gathering events ===
Immediately after the spikes of the cases which related to the Sri Petaling Tabligh event
column2: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announces that all events that involving mass gathering in any genre including international
column3: religious
column4: sports
column5: meetups and social must be cancelled or postponed until 30 April 2020. However
column6: the end date for the ban on mass gathering events are subject to revision depending on the situation of the outbreak. In addition
column7: Registrar of Societies (RoS) bans all parties registered with RoS from organising any meeting and activities until 30 June 2020.

column1: === Impact on schools ===
The Ministry of Education of Malaysia announces that all extracurricular activity in schools will be suspended starting from March 2020 until further notice.On 15 April
column2: the Education Minister Mohd Radzi Md Jidin announced that the Ujian Penilaian Sekolah Rendah (UPSR) and Pentaksiran Tingkatan Tiga (PT3) examinations for standard six and form three students have been cancelled for 2020 in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. He also announced that all other major school examinations including the Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia (SPM) and Sijil Tinggi Persekolahan Malaysia (STPM) would be postponed to 2021 and August 2020 respectively.On 23 June
column3: the Ministry of Education announced changes to school term holidays in order to help schools better plan lessons that had been disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic and Movement Control Order. The mid-term break would be reduced from nine days to five days. The end of the year break in schools in Group A states (Johor
column4: Kedah
column5: Kelantan
column6: and  Terengganu) would be reduced from 42 days to 14 days. The end of the year break in Group B states (Malacca
column7: Negri Sembilan
column8: Pahang
column9: Perak
column10: Perlis
column16: Labuan and Putrajaya) would be reduced from 41 days to 13 days. The Education Ministry confirmed that the school year for 2020 will now total 168 days. In response
column17: former Education Minister Maszlee Malik criticised the Ministry for not consulting with teachers and teachers' unions including the National Union of the Teaching Profession and West Malaysia Malay Teachers Union prior to amending the school term.

column1: === Economic stimulus plan ===
On 27 March
column2: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin launched an economic stimulus package known as the "caring package" worth RM250 billion. Of these
column3: RM128 billion was used to protect the welfare of the people and RM100 billion to support businesses
column4: including small and medium enterprises (SMEs).The government also announced a RM600 million allocation on 23 March to the Ministry of Health for the purchase of equipment and to hire contract personnel
column5: especially nurses. It has also announced that contributors of the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) can withdraw up to RM500 per month for 12 months.An allocation of RM130 million has also been announced and will be distributed equally to all states to help overcome the COVID-19 pandemic. The details of the plan are:

column1: Budget of RM500 million to the Ministry of Health to enhance the health and resources of the ministry.
The government raises special allowances for healthcare workers from RM400 to RM600 a month from 1 April until the end of the pandemic.
Additional special allowance of RM200 per month for frontliner for police

column3: Customs Department
column4: Malaysian Civil Defence Force and RELA Corps personnel.

column8: 000 and below; RM500 for Malaysians aged 21 and over earns between RM2
column9: 000 and RM4

Free internet from April onwards until the end of the MCO.
The joint government of TNB will increase the allocation of RM530 million for a discount of between 15% and 50% for electricity usage up to 600 kW per month for six months from the April bill.
Exemption of rent for Program Perumahan Rakyat and public housing for six months.
Insurance and takaful companies set aside RM8 million to cover COVID-19 inspection costs up to RM300 per policyholder.
Government to provide a payment of RM500 to approximately 120
column2: 000 e-hailing drivers starting 1 April.

column1: The Government and Bank Negara Malaysia will set aside an additional allocation of RM4.5 billion for SMEs and micro-entrepreneurs which will consist of five initiatives.
One-off RM500 aid for 120
column2: 000 e-hailing drivers nationwide with an allocation of RM60 million. This is in addition to the one-time assistance announced for taxi drivers announced in the previous stimulus package.

column1: The government will pay the salaries incurred by contractors involved in the service sector
column2: such as cleaning services and food supplies cooked at government agencies.

column1: The government will introduce a subsidy of RM600 a month for three months for employers with a 50% reduction since 1 January

column1: The government will continue all projects allocated in the 2020 Budget

column3: MRT2 and the National Sustainability and Sustainability Plan (NFCP) in line with its focus on ensuring sustainable economic development.

column1: Human Resources Development Fund (HRDF) is tax-exempted for all sectors for six months beginning April 2020.
Federal government premises such as school cafeteria
column2: nursery

column1: Government pensioners to receive RM500 cash assistance.Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin launched a special stimulus plan on 6 April
column2: worth RM10 billion aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to mitigate the impact of action control orders (MCO). Muhyiddin said that SMEs and micro-enterprises accounted for two-thirds of the country's manpower and contributed 40% of the country's economy. This is in addition to other economic stimulus plans that increase cash flow to ensure that the economy will not collapse.On 5 June
column3: the Prime Minister announced the Short-Term Economic Recovery Plan (Penjana) to alleviate the effects of the pandemic. The details of the plan are:

column1: Nearly RM9 billion to address rising unemployment.
The Wage Subsidy Programme to be extended for another three months.
Employers can apply for the Wage Subsidy Programme if they were not allowed to operate during CMCO.
Penjana has 40 initiatives worth RM35 billion
column2: of which RM10 billion is a direct fiscal injection by the government.

column1: An employment subsidy programme worth RM1.5 billion for companies hiring unemployed people.
Companies that employ Malaysians under 40 to be given RM800 per worker while those that employ Malaysians above 40 or disabled people to be given RM1
column3: for a period of six months.

column1: Public transport users can pay RM30 per month for unlimited rides from 15 June to 31 December.

E-vouchers for those ordering childcare services online.
Up to RM3
column2: 000 incentive of individual income tax for fees paid by parents to daycare centres and kindergartens.

column3: 000 per SME.

Cash-flow aid by SME Bank for G2 and G3 contractors that are awarded minor government projects.

The Penjana Nasional fund worth RM600 million to drive the process of digitalisation of businesses and innovation.
RM75 million for draft policies related to the gig economy.

RM75 million to e-wallets

RM50 million for the Malaysian Investment Development Authority for promotional and marketing activities.

=== Fighting misinformation ===
Some people have been arrested for allegedly spreading false information about the COVID-19 pandemic. As of May 17
column3: police and the Malaysian Communication and Multimedia Commission (MCMC) have opened 265 investigations on COVID-19 related fake news. A total of 30 people have been charged
column4: 11 were served with a warning notice and 18 others pleaded guilty.

column1: === Face masks ===
On 23 July
column2: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that it will be compulsory for people to wear face masks in public spaces such as markets and public transportation from 1 August
column3: with violators facing a RM1

column1: == Implications ==
=== Animal welfare ===
On 25 June
column2: The Sun Daily reported that animal shelters were facing financial difficulties while having to take care of numerous unwanted cats and dogs. The Lost Souls Animal Souls Shelter in Kuala Selangor had taken to growing organic vegetables in order to cover its operating expenses. Under the Animal Welfare Act
column3: abandoning pet animals is an offense punishable by a fine of between RM20
column4: 000 and RM100
column5: 000 or a jail term of up to three years.

column1: === Births and deaths registrations ===
On 19 April
column2: Defence Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that registration of births and deaths during the movement control order (MCO) will be allowed to be delayed up to 90 days from the date the MCO ends. Ismail Sabri also announced that the Ministry of Home Affairs had decided that those who needed to replace their lost MyKad identity cards could make an appointment with local National Registration Department branches.

column1: === Economy
column2: trade and tourism ===

column1: Stocks on Malaysia's stock exchange of Bursa Malaysia tumbled during the outbreak as investors sold securities due to the expected economic impact caused by the virus
column2: which along with other emerging stock markets are predicted to remain until June 2020. With China as Malaysia's largest trading partner
column3: the country's economy was directly impacted and economic experts have warned the prolonged virus outbreak could hit the country gross domestic product (GDP) hard. Malaysia which also largely relied on tourism and being among the top destinations for Chinese tourists
column4: suffered a stark decline of tourist arrival from Mainland China due to the outbreak with the tourism industry hit hardest; costing around RM3.37 billion losses until March. Malaysian states highly dependent on tourism sectors and being the point for Mainland Chinese visitors such as Johor
column5: Malacca
column6: Penang
column7: and Sabah were among the heaviest affected with hotel bookings and food stalls have reported large loss in businesses. These subsequently forced the states to shift their focus to the Southeast Asian market due to the decline of Mainland Chinese tourists. Regardless the large losses incurred by tourism businesses
column8: a number of Malaysians have voiced their concerns over the spread of the virus and urging a ban on travellers from China to the country with some 149
column9: 000 in support of the call. Aberdeen Standard Investments of Malaysia also predicted the country currency of Malaysian ringgit (MYR) to weaken further throughout the local and worldwide outbreak which exacerbate further by instable local political scene in the country.Due to the cancellation of the Ramadan bazaars
column10: many Malaysian traders have use online platforms such as WhatsApp and Facebook to sell their products.On 27 June
column12: Arts and Culture Minister Datuk Seri Nancy Shukri estimated that the tourism and cultural sectors had lost RM45 billion as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. In response
column13: the Government introduced a Special Fund for Tourism to help small and medium-sized businesses affected by COVID-19.

column1: === Panic buying and essential item shortages ===

The increase in cases and public awareness on the threat posed by the virus has exacerbated panic buying of surgical masks and hand sanitisers which were selling like hot cakes within a short period. Malaysian cities
column2: such as Johor Bahru and Kota Kinabalu
column3: have reported shortages on surgical masks
column4: while a cleaning company in Shah Alam reported a higher demand for hand sanitisers due to the outbreak. There were reports that some pharmacies and traders have been selling masks with higher prices than the controlled price set by the Domestic Trade and Consumer Affairs Ministry of Malaysia which can lead to fines of up to RM10
column6: 387). This also includes reports of some people being scammed by unscrupulous individuals taking advantage of the pandemic situation
column7: with a further total of 501 fraud cases involving losses amounting to RM3.5 million reported throughout the MCO period resulting to the arrests of 37 scammers. Despite the increasing shortages of masks in the country with both pharmacies and suppliers struggling to meet the increasing demands
column8: the federal government has assured the supply of masks to be replenished with a total of 10 million masks to enter Malaysian markets in the nearest time. With the rapid spread of the virus infections into several more states such as Penang and Sabah in the country
column9: panic buying has seen an increase nationwide with people began to packing excessive essential items. This causing some of the major supermarket operators in the country to continuously assured the public that there is adequate supply of essentials and urging most people to not engage in panic buying despite the recently announced move by the federal government to impose movement control within the country. The federal government also in the consideration to ban face masks exports as a result of the increasing mask shortages with the Domestic Trade and Consumer Affairs Ministry to raise the increasing shortages issues of surgical masks and hand sanitisers to the Malaysian Cabinet. On 18 March
column10: the enforcement to ban face masks export was gazetted under the Control of Supplies (Prohibition on Export) – (Amendment) Regulations 2020 covering four type of face masks. Apart from enacting law banning face masks exports to meet the struggling domestic public demands
column11: the federal government announced that it will import 10 million face masks from China by stages to increase nationwide supply and assisting the frontliners with the importation of face masks from other countries also being allowed. A further total of 24.62 million face masks to be distributed among Malaysians nationwide has been announced by the federal government on 8 April.

column1: === Sporting and other events ===

The pandemic outbreak has forced the cancellations and postponements of many events in the country; including both local and international. All sports and co-curricular activities in schools were postponed with immediate effects as announced by the country Ministry of Education. Major Anglican and Catholic Masses in West Malaysia as well as in Sabah and Sarawak were also postponed
column2: while annual cultural events in Sabah such as the Kaamatan (Kadazan-Dusun festival) and Kalimaran (Murut festival) have been cancelled. Despite Muslim Friday sermon (except for the state of Perlis on 13 March) are not suspended in the earlier stages of the virus spread
column3: the Yang-di Pertuan Agong of Malaysia has called for shorter sermon and every mosques in the country must provide forehead thermometer
column4: hand sanitiser and face masks as part of the prevention measures. A guidelines on Friday sermon has been released by the Religious Affairs Minister of Malaysia. Finally on 17 March
column5: every mosque and suraus activities including Friday sermons and congregational prayers postponement were announced after receiving the permissible order by Yang di-Pertuan Agong which covering all states with a sultan while other states without a sultan shall refer to the announcement made by their respective state muftis. Malaysia's ethnic Chinese Qingming Festival have been hung fire while Hindu temple festival and also Vaisakhi gatherings have been cancelled. With the Malaysia national football team will play the 2022 World Cup qualifiers
column6: the Malaysians planned to play a friendly game against Bahrain before facing the UAE and Vietnam. It was later announced that the friendly would not take part due to severe outbreak in Malaysia and
column7: later
column8: Bahrain. Further sporting events such as golf's Maybank Championship and other local tournament were immediately called off while other sporting events such as the 2020 Sukma Games
column9: badminton's Malaysia Open
column10: football's M-League
column12: squash's Asian Team Championship and Malaysian Schools Sports Council events were either cancelled or postponed.

column1: == Relaxation of restrictions ==
On 1 May
column2: the Malaysian Government announced that it will be relaxing Movement Control Order restrictions from 4 May as part of its plan to gradually restart the country's economy. Transport Minister Dr Wee Ka Siong confirmed that all public transportation services would resume on 4 May. As part of the fourth phase of the Movement Control Order
column3: two family members will be allowed to buy food and other daily essentials. The easing of MCO drew criticisms from politicians and healthcare experts over concerns that it was too much too soon
column4: and by 3 May
column5: over 420
column6: 000 members of the public had signed a petition objecting to the conditional MCO and calling for the government to stay with the MCO.On 3 October
column7: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that the Malaysian Government would not be re-imposing lockdown measures despite a spike in cases as the majority of cases were reported in detention centres and isolated districts.

column1: === Commerce ===
On 7 June
column2: the Mayor of Kuala Lumpur Nor Hisham Ahmad Dahlan announced that the Kuala Lumpur City Hall will allow open markets
column3: morning markets
column4: night markets and bazaars to reopen in stages after the implementation of the Recovery Movement Control Order on 15 June.On 22 June
column5: Senior Minister (Security Cluster) Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that cinemas
column6: theatres and other live events would be allowed to reopen from 1 July
column7: with a limit of 250 people.On 10 July
column8: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that family entertainment centres including game arcades
column9: karaoke centres
column10: indoor funfairs
column12: and kids' gymnasiums can resume operations from 15 July. However
column15: and night clubs cannot reopen yet.

column1: === Education ===
On 3 June
column2: Education Minister Dr Mohd Radzi Md Jidin announced that the Government would be distributing guidelines for reopening schools to teachers on 4 June as part of efforts to reopen the education sector. On 6 June
column3: Director-General of Health Noor Hisham Abdullah announced that hair and beauty salons will be able to reopen on 10 June.On 10 June
column4: Education Minister Mohd Radzi Md Jidin confirmed that schools in the country would begin reopening in stages from 24 June
column5: with priority being given to students taking secondary and equivalent international leaving exams. As part of social distancing measures
column6: schools will serve pre-packaged food and all students will have their temperatures checked when entering schools.On 26 June
column7: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that tuition centres
column8: special education schools and private schools would be allowed to operate soon.On 29 June
column9: it was reported that both public and private pre-schools
column10: kindergartens
column11: nurseries and day care centres would resume operations from 1 July. In addition
column12: several businesses have been allowed to reopen including spas
column15: theatres and "live" event venues. The Government has also allowed a range of social functions including meetings
column24: and religious gatherings to be held. In addition
column28: gated community and private pools have also been allowed.On 1 July
column29: the Education Minister Mohd Radzi announced that schools for other students will reopen in two stages from 15 July.  Forms One to Four students
column31: remove class students and Form Six Semester 1 students will return on 15 July while Years One to Four primary school pupils will return to school on 22 July. He also confirmed that the 2021 academic year would be decided at a later date.On 14 July
column32: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that driving schools would be allowed to resume their courses and training.

column1: === Marriages ===
On 21 June
column2: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that couples whose marriage registration had been delayed as a result of the Movement Control Order could not complete the process at all permitted NGOs in the country including clan organisations
column3: temples
column4: churches
column5: and religious bodies. On 22 June
column6: Yaakob announced that the Government would announce on Wednesday (24 June) whether the ceremonies would be allowed soon.

column1: === Places of worship ===
On 28 May
column2: the Ministry of National Unity announced that a total of 174 non-Muslim houses of worship have been allowed to resume operations from 10 June according to the Standard Operating Procedure for Houses of Worship in Green Zones including having a maximum number of 30 worshipers
column3: subject to the size of the premises. These house of worships include those under Fo Guang Shan; the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kuala Lumpur
column4: the National Evangelical Christian Fellowship
column5: the Malaysia Hindu Sangam
column6: the Malaysian Gurdwaras Council
column7: and the Federation of Taoist Associations Malaysia. Marriages at temples
column8: churches
column9: and religious associations have been postponed until 31 July 2020.On 15 June
column10: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that all 5
column11: 230 non-Muslim places of worship would be allowed to reopen but had to adhere to social distancing guidelines including taking one-third of their usual capacity and requiring attendees to download the MySejahtera application.On 3 July
column12: Minister in the Prime Minister's Department (Religious Affairs) Dr Zulkifli Mohamad Al-Bakri clarified that foreigners would not be allowed to attend congregational prayers at mosques and surau until the Department had studied reports from the Federal Territories Islamic Religious Department regarding the situation in mosques and surau.

column1: === Tourism ===
On 26 June
column2: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that sectors and industries under the purview of the Ministry of Tourism
column3: Arts and Culture such as such as meetings
column4: incentives
column5: conventions and exhibitions
column6: travel and trade fairs
column7: spa
column8: wellness and reflexology centres would be allowed to open from 1 July. However
column9: tourism businesses are required to abide by social distancing measures
column10: limit crowds to 200-250 people
column13: and provide hand sanitisers. While reflexology centers provided by the blind are allowed to reopen
column14: only Malaysians can work in spas

column1: === Travel ===
On 7 June
column2: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that interstate travel would be allowed from 10 June except in areas classified under the Enhanced Movement Control Order (EMCO).On 13 June
column3: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that Malaysians from peninsular Malaysia
column4: Sabah
column5: and Labuan would be allowed to enter Sarawak without having to seek permission from the Sarawak Disaster Management Committee (SDMC) and take COVID-19 PCR tests prior to leaving for the state.On 27 June
column6: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and his Singaporean counterpart Lee Hsien Loong agreed that their governments would collaborate to establish a Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) allowing residents from both nations who hold long-term immigration passes for business and work purposes in the other country to periodically return to their home countries for short-term home leave.On 14 July
column7: Malaysian Foreign Minister Hishammuddin Hussein and Singaporean Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan announced that cross-border travel and traffic between the two countries will resume on 10 August 2020 under two schemes: the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) and the Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA). The Reciprocal Green Lane will allow essential business and official travel between the two countries while the Periodic Commuting Arrangement will allow Singaporean and Malaysian residents who hold long-term immigration business and work passes to enter for work purposes.On 23 July
column8: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that all travellers entering Malaysia would have to undergo mandatory quarantine at hotels and quarantine centres commencing 24 July.  On 30 July
column9: Immigration Department director-general Datuk Khairul Dzaimee warned that foreigners refusing to pay the mandatory quarantine costs of RM 4
column10: 700 would have their long-term social visa passes revoked. Malaysians only have to pay half the quarantine cost.

column1: == Funds and aid on the pandemic ==
=== Exchange of aid between Malaysia and other countries ===
==== January–February aid to China ====
Malaysian aid organisation #OpsHarapan aimed to collect 10
column2: 000 N95 face masks for its relief efforts to Wuhan. A total of 18 million pieces of medical gloves were donated by Malaysia to assist China in their struggle against the virus. The Malaysia's state Government of Sabah has raised RM2 million for the "Wuhan Fund" which will be channelled to China as a sign of solidarity with the country during the outbreak. The state government fund's earlier target was RM1 million although the amount received exceeded the initial target when a local philanthropist contributed RM40
column4: 548). The fundraising was organised in a joint event called "We Love
column5: We Care" by the Sabah government and Chinese associations. A group of musicians in Malaysia also published a song to support China in their struggle against the virus titled "You Are Not Alone" which was featured in a show in Malaysia's capital of Kuala Lumpur.

column1: ==== March–April aid to Malaysia ====
On 23 March 2020
column2: the Malaysian government urged local PPE manufacturers to step their production due to reports that Malaysia's healthcare workers faced a shortage of PPE
column3: resorting to clingwrap and plastic wrap for making DIY protective suits which had to be changed up to 5 times per day. On 16 March 2020
column4: Malaysia's Prime Minister announced that the Chinese ambassador in Malaysia has declared China's willingness to help by supplying face masks and disinfectants. The first medical supplies were sent to Sungai Buloh Hospital on 19 March. A further 100
column5: 000 face masks were sent by the President of China-Asia Economic Development Association to Malaysia. Along the same day
column6: Chinese Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma further announced that through his foundation
column7: a total of 2 million masks
column9: 000 test kits
column12: 000 face shields will be sent to four Southeast Asian countries including Malaysia to aid these nations in their struggle against the virus. A further total of 1
column16: 100 protective clothing and 100 goggles were contributed by China specifically for the Malaysian police forces. China's Consulate-General in Kota Kinabalu also has announced that medical aid to be dispatched to Sabah to aid their struggle against the virus and reciprocate the people's of Sabah recent assistance to Mainland China during the outbreak. On 25 March
column18: 500 test kits were delivered to Malaysia's Health Ministry by China through its several business entities operating in Malaysia. On 26 March
column20: 000 N95 face masks were delivered by China for the Malaysia's state of Sarawak frontline healthcare workers. By 29 March
column21: China delivered a total of 83 boxes of face masks with 2
column22: 000 pieces to Malaysia's state of Sabah. A further 170
column27: hand sanitisers and surgical masks were delivered by China to the Sabah state government on 30 March. Another 20
column28: 000 surgical masks destined for Sabah's healthcare frontliner workers were delivered in early April. A total of 30
column29: 000 face masks were delivered by China through its Consulate General in Kuching specifically for the Sarawak State Disaster Management Committee. Malaysia has asked China's medical experts to share their experience with Malaysia's frontliners
column30: to be accomplished through a videoconference between their doctors on 26 March 2020. On 13 April 2020
column31: Malaysia's health ministry announced that Malaysian hospitals will run out of PPE supplies in two weeks
column32: calling upon NGO's and other parties to donate their PPE supplies.

column1: === Aid from other countries ===
The Malaysian government was also given aid from the United Arab Emirates
column2: which included 600
column3: 000 face masks
column4: 200 ventilators
column5: about 100
column6: 000 test kits and 50
column7: 000 protective clothings. Neighbouring Singapore had donated 5
column8: 000 universal transport medium (UTM) swabs
column9: a critical component in test kits which can test for a case of the virus within minutes. Malaysia also among the seven countries in Taiwan further aid lists following the former request of face masks supplies
column10: with Taiwan has began to starting its second round of surgical mask donations to severely hit countries in Latin America and Southeast Asia from 9 April after its donations to Europe and the United States been fulfilled. Taiwanese Tzu Chi foundation also donating essential food and equipment to hospitals and clinics in Malaysia. Turkey-based Independent Industrialists' and Businessmen's Association's (MUSIAD) had distribute free face masks to shoppers at a mall in Malaysia's capital of Kuala Lumpur on 11 April to assist the country efforts in their fight against the virus. Macdonald's Malaysia which is part of an American fast-food franchise donated food to about 50 hospitals in the country
column13: and also to other frontliners such as the police and army personnel.

column1: === Local pandemic fund within Malaysia ===
Following the severely strained healthcare system due to the increasing number of infections by the virus
column2: Mercy Malaysia launched the "Covid-19 Pandemic Fund" to supporting medical services and the essential needs of marginalised groups within the country. Various Malaysian crowdfunding platforms joined hands in raising money to supply frontline health workers with critical protective equipment and supplies. The Malaysian Red Crescent Society also launched the #responsMALAYSIA (Malaysia's Response) initiative to support frontliners.Various Malaysian states have launched their own stimulus packages and announced immediate financial aid in the form of rental waivers and deferment of student loan repayments to help their citizens to cope throughout the virus outbreak with the federal government of Malaysia also announced it will disburse a total of RM130 million equally among Malaysia's 13 states to help small traders
column3: the infected victims and front-line staff especially those in the healthcare sector. The country Prime Minister
column4: Deputy Prime Minister
column5: all other ministers and deputy ministers had contribute two months of their salaries to the COVID-19 Fund of Malaysia has been announced by the Prime Minister's Office statement issued on 26 March.In February
column6: Malaysia's home improvement retailer MR DIY distributed a total of 3.5 million free face masks nationwide to help curb the spread of the virus. Further in March
column7: Coway Malaysia donated a total of 100
column8: 000 pieces of surgical face masks to PDRM in an effort to help safeguard police personnel who are on the frontlines during the global pandemic.Various Malaysian banks such as Affin Bank
column9: Agrobank
column10: Alliance Bank
column23: RHB Bank and SME Bank has offered measures including financial assistance for its customers amidst the virus crisis.

column1: ==== Local broadcasting and telecommunications companies aid ====
To keep the Malaysian public entertained during the movement control order period
column2: both Malaysia's pay television and internet services of Unifi offers free access to all Unifi TV channels while its mobile prepaid of Unifi Mobile offers unlimited data. Astro also offers free access to all of its paid movie channels through both basic Astro and Astro GO mobile application. Starting from 1 April
column3: all telecommunication companies in the country have been instructed by the government to provide free internet data usage to their respective customers throughout the movement control order period has been published in the website of Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission (MCMC). The MCMC has announced that Malaysia's mobile telecommunication companies of Celcom
column4: Digi
column5: Maxis and U Mobile will be offering its prepaid and postpaid customers free 1GB of high-speed data
column6: which is to be used daily between 8 am to 6 pm.

column1: ==== Government relief assistance ====
On 27 March
column2: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin launched the federal government's RM250 billion Prihatin stimulus package to help people
column3: businesses and the economy to weather the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Prihatin stimulus package consists of RM128 billion for welfare assistance
column4: RM100 billion to support small and medium businesses
column5: RM2 billion to strengthen the country's economy
column6: and a RM20 billion stimulus package that was previously announced by the government. The regional economist Brian Tan from Barclays
column7: said that the central bank would cut interest rates to 1%.

column1: == Controversies ==
=== Failure to contain the Tabligh cluster amidst a political crisis ===
Following significant increases in COVID-19 cases in the country originating from the Tablighi Jamaat gathering at "Masjid Jamek Sri Petaling" in Kuala Lumpur
column2: attention has been directed at the failure of the leadership of the country preventing such large gatherings from being held and containing the spread of the cluster case.Until 24 February
column3: Malaysia was under a Pakatan Harapan (PH) government
column4: which Ministry of Health under Dzulkefly Ahmad had collaborated with Director-General of Health Noor Hisham Abdullah to prepare for the intake of COVID-19 patients
column5: and had overseen the first month of the outbreak since 25 January with low volumes of cases
column6: primarily imported. The Tabligh gathering
column7: held from 27 February to 1 March
column8: occurred within a week after the start of a major political crisis
column9: which saw the collapse of the PH government on 24 February as a result of the defection of the Malaysian United Indigenous Party (PPBM) from the PH coalition
column10: and an absence of a government until the formation of an unelected Perikatan Nasional (PN) government comprising a coalition of Opposition parties on 29 February. The Health Ministry would not have a minister for over two weeks until the appointment of Adham Baba on 10 March
column11: just as spikes in cases began to be reported.Adham would later use the Tabligh cluster incident to attack the previous PH government. In a 18 April 2020 livestreamed video conference call with Ahmad Zahid Hamidi
column12: President of United Malays National Organisation (UMNO) (a major component party in the PN government)
column13: Adham would accuse PH of failing to prevent the spread of the Tabligh cluster despite the absence of a functional government during the period
column14: while erroneously referring to the gathering as having taken place for longer
column16: and claiming to have attended a World Health Organization (WHO) conference call with "500 countries" (which Adham later clarified to refer to "500 participants from all around the world"). Responding to Adham's accusation
column17: Dzulkefly would rebuke Adham's politicisation of the health crisis
column18: claimed that preparations have been made since December 2019
column19: and suggested that prior knowledge of the gathering would more likely be known to the Minister of Home Affairs of the previous PH government
column21: who at the time of the political crisis spearheaded a defection of PPBM from PH and has subsequently been appointed as the current Prime Minister for the PN government.

column1: === Advice from the Health Ministry ===
During a televised interview on Radio Televisyen Malaysia (RTM)'s Bicara Naratif on 19 March 2020
column2: Health Minister Adham Baba advised the public that drinking warm water will help prevent COVID-19 infection as the virus will be flushed down to the stomach and the digestive acids will kill any virus. His remarks went viral on social media
column3: with many netizens questioning his claim. Dr. Nur Amalina Che Bakri had criticised Adham
column4: stating that there is no research evidence that stomach acid can kill the virus. Similarly
column5: Director-General of Health Noor Hisham Abdullah disputes Adham's statement
column6: commenting that the Health Ministry's approach for patient treatment and management is always based on evidence. The remedy is thought to have originated as a commonly circulated social media post
column7: and has been widely debunked by health experts
column8: including the WHO
column9: which has stated that while staying hydrated by drinking water is important for overall health
column10: it does not prevent coronavirus infection.

column1: === Insufficient facemasks and pricing ===
Despite the country having four manufacturers of face masks with higher quality and also expensive price
column2: minimal support was given by the government to these manufacturers to sustain their operations. Most of the masks produced by Malaysia were exported to high-income developed countries with little being supplied to the country's own healthcare institutions whereas 90% of face masks for these sectors and Malaysian markets originated from Mainland China
column3: Taiwan
column4: South Korea
column5: India and Thailand. With the countries local manufacturers struggling to fulfil the increasing overseas demands and with difficulties securing raw materials from China due to the outbreak
column6: they were forced to seek materials from Europe which subsequently raised the price of masks. On 13 April
column7: the Ministry of Health warned that supplies of personal protective equipment (PPE) were running low with only 2 weeks of stocks left.

column1: === Advice from the Women Ministry ===
On 31 March
column2: in a campaign to avoid domestic conflict during the Movement Control Order period
column3: the Ministry of Women
column4: Family and Community Development released online posters advising women to dress up and wear make-up while working from home
column5: refrain from sarcasm while asking for help with household chores
column6: avoid nagging and attempt to inject humour by mimicking Doraemon's voice. The posters attracted widespread ridicule and were criticised for being sexist
column7: stereotyping women and insinuating that women are responsible for domestic conflict. In response
column8: the Ministry took down the posters and apologised in a statement for "tips that were inappropriate and touched on the sensitivities of certain groups".

column1: === Quarantine regulations in the University of Malaya ===
Student volunteers at the University of Malaya claim they are designed to deal with the "quarantine" of students returning from China in the new semester.
=== Treatment of MCO violators ===
In an 26 April 2020 report
column2: Human Rights Watch criticised the Malaysian authorities for imprisoning people for violating the country's movement control order
column3: putting their lives at a relatively greater risk of being infected by the virus. More than 15
column4: 000 people have already been arrested for going against the orders on 18 March 2020.

column1: === Treatment of foreigners ===
According to Human Rights Watch and the Asia Pacific Refugee Rights Network
column2: over 700 foreign migrant workers and refugees including Rohingya have been detained by Malaysian police during the coronavirus pandemic. In response to the arrests
column3: the United Nations in Malaysia's Head of Communications and Advocacy
column4: Ahmad Hafiz Osman
column5: called for migrants
column6: refugees
column7: asylum seekers
column8: and stateless individuals to have access to health services and services without any fear of repercussions. On 11 May
column9: 83 human rights and civil society organisations including Human Rights Watch
column10: Amnesty International
column12: and the International Committee of Jurists have called on Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to address online hate speech and violent threats against Rohingya refugees in Malaysia.On 5 June
column13: National Security Council Sabah director Sharifah Sitti Saleha Habib Yussof confirmed that 5
column14: 300 Filipino "illegal immigrants" had been "stranded" at temporary detention centres in Sabah after the Philippines government refused to repatriate them due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines. Between 1 January and 17 March 2020
column22: and Bangladeshi nationals prior to the implementation of the country's Movement Control Order on 18 March. Since the imposition of a Condition Movement Control Order in May
column23: Sabah authorities have repatriated 322 Indonesian illegal immigrants.On 21 June
column24: Malaysian human rights NGO Aliran raised concerns about the living and working conditions of foreign migrant workers in Malaysia
column25: many of whom had contracted COVID-19. Aliran also criticised "inflammatory" media coverage for fueling xenophobia and hostility against migrant workers.On 25 June
column26: the Kuala Lumpur City Hall curtailed refugees' access to the city's wholesale market
column27: only allowing them entry if they possessed valid permits and were accompanied by Malaysians. The City Hall's decision also barred entry by refugees carrying cards issued by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. This ruling was criticised by Yemen Refugee Union representative Dr Mohammed Al Radhi and Alliance of Chin Refugees coordinator James Bawi Thang Bik as discriminatory and inhumane towards refugees.On 27 June
column28: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin issued a statement that Malaysia could not take any more Rohingya refugees due to a struggling economy and dwindling resources. Malaysia does not recognise their refugee status and has turned away boats and detained hundreds of Rohingya refugees. Muhyiddin also urged the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to speed up the resettlement of Rohingya refugees in third party countries.

column1: In early July 2020
column2: an Al Jazeera documentary titled "Locked Up in Malaysia's Lockdown" alleged that illegal migrants and foreign workers had been mistreated by the Malaysian authorities and subject to racism during the country's lockdown. The Malaysian Government criticised the documentary as "misleading" and "inaccurate"
column3: with Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob demanding an apology from the news network. The Royal Malaysian Police have launched an investigation into the documentary while the Immigration Department of Malaysia have sought to question a Bangladeshi migrant interviewed in the documentary. In response
column4: several civil society organisations including the Centre for Independent Journalism (CIJ) issued a statement calling on the Malaysian Government to cease intimidatory measures against media and prevent incitement to discrimination
column5: hostility
column6: and violence against migrant workers. The Bangladeshi migrant
column7: who was identified as Mohammad Rayhan Kaybir was subsequently deported to Bangladesh on 22 August.On 13 August
column8: Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced that foreigners entering Malaysia would have to pay quarantine charges and COVID-19 detection tests upon entering the country.
